sections.title: Game Start
content: Each player starts with a personal deck of 54 cards.
They draw 7 cards at the beginning of the game.
From these 7 cards, 2 cards of their choice are placed face down in reserve, on the field.
The player therefore keeps 5 cards in hand, and 2 cards in reserve.
sections.highlight: ğŸ§  Important reminder: The reserve is a strategic extension of the hand, it remains face down and accessible during the game.

sections.title: Turn Structure
content: Each turn always follows the same sequence.

sections.title: Case 1: The player starts their turn with 7 cards
sections.subtitle: (5 in hand + 2 in reserve)
content: Mandatory Discard: The player must discard 1 card from their hand (their choice).
Draw: Then, they draw 1 card to return to a total of 7 cards.
Action Phase: They can then:
â€¢ Place cards to build units,
â€¢ Use a special card (Jack, King, etc.),
â€¢ Attack or activate an effect.
End of Turn: Once their actions are finished, the player announces the end of their turn.
sections.warning: ğŸ›‘ If the player cannot or does not want to perform any action, they must mandatory indicate the end of their turn.

sections.title: Case 2: The player has fewer than 7 cards at the start of the turn
sections.subtitle: (because they played cards previously)
content: The player immediately draws the number of cards needed to return to 7 cards (hand + reserve).
Then they enter the action phase: they can play, attack, activate an effect...
End of Turn: they end their turn as usual.

sections.title: General Reminder
content: Players can never exceed 7 cards (5 in hand + 2 in reserve).
If at 7 at the start of the turn: must discard 1 card before drawing.
If played cards: draws directly, without discard.
Each turn, a player can act or pass, but must indicate it.

sections.title: The Action Phase
content: During their turn, after drawing, the player enters their action phase.
They can perform several types of actions, in the order they wish, as long as they respect the following limits:

sections.title: Available Actions
content: Each action costs 1 action, except for special cases.
Here is the list of main actions a player can perform during their turn:

sections.title: 1. Play a card to build a unit
content: The player places a card in the corresponding column (by suit).
Units must be placed in ascending order, from Ace to 10.
sections.highlight: â¡ï¸ âœ… This action allows progress towards an attack or a Revolution.

sections.title: 2. Play a special card (Jack, King, Queen)
content: The player can summon a special card by:
â€¢ Sacrifice (cards already placed),
â€¢ Using a Joker,
â€¢ Or a Lucky 7.
Summoning counts as an action.
sections.highlight: ğŸ’¡ Exception: If a Jack is summoned by Joker or sacrifice, it can attack immediately in the same turn. (Otherwise, it is passive until the next turn.)

sections.title: 3. Attack with a unit
content: A unit can attack only once in its category.
This attack costs 1 action.
sections.warning: âš ï¸ After an attack, the entire unit category is deactivated, even if the attack is blocked.

sections.title: 4. Swap a card with an already placed Joker
content: If a Joker is placed on the field to replace a card, the player can replace it with the real card (same suit and value).
The Joker returns to the hand or reserve depending on its origin.
sections.highlight: â¡ï¸ âœ… This swap counts as an action.

sections.title: 5. Defense during the opponent's turn
content: Although defense does not occur during the player's action phase, it is important to know about it.
A player can block an opponent's attack:
â€¢ If they possess a JOKER (in hand or reserve) â†’ they play it immediately, it blocks the attack.
â€¢ If a Lucky 7 is present in the attacked column, at the right place (after the 6), then:
- It blocks a single attack.
- It is then deactivated until the column is destroyed and rebuilt.
sections.highlight: ğŸ§  To remember: A Joker can block any attack (except Revolution). A Joker can block any attack, regardless of the column, except a Revolution. Each defense is valid once, then the card goes to the grave or becomes inactive.

sections.title: Action Limits
content: The player can perform as many actions as they wish in their turn, as long as they have cards to do so.
However:
â€¢ They can only make one Joker swap per turn.
â€¢ They can only attack once per unit category.
â€¢ Some cards (Jack) do not attack immediately, except in special cases.

sections.title: End of Turn
content: Once all actions are finished, the player announces the end of their turn.
If they perform no action, they must still declare the end of their turn.

sections.title: Activators: Lucky 7 & Joker
content: In UNIT, to build a unit column, it is not enough to place cards in order. You must activate the column with a special card called an activator.
There are two types of activators:
â€¢ ğŸŸ¦ The Lucky 7
â€¢ ğŸƒ The Joker

sections.title: How to activate a column?
content: To start a column, you must place an Ace, then climb progressively up to the 6.
This activator is placed in a special zone of the column, called reserveSuitColonne.
sections.highlight: ğŸ§  But to be able to go beyond the 6 (and play the 8, 9, 10), it is mandatory to have an activator in place.

sections.title: How an activator works
content: When a Lucky 7 or a Joker is played as an activator:
â€¢ It is placed next to the column, in the reserveSuitColonne.
â€¢ It unlocks the climb towards the 8, 9, 10.
â€¢ It remains active as long as the column is not destroyed.

sections.title: Example
content: You have cards from Ace to 6 in Diamonds.
You place a Lucky 7 of Diamonds in the reserveSuitColonne.
You can now place the 8, 9, 10 of Diamonds.

sections.title: Watch out for conditions!
content: A Joker or any Lucky 7 can be played at the start of the game to open the play, even if it doesn't match the suit.
sections.highlight: âœ… This allows advancing and adapting your strategy.
sections.warning: âŒ But to pass from card 6 to 8 in a column, you must mandatory have the correct Lucky 7 of the same suit as the column.

sections.title: Swapping the activator
content: If you placed the wrong 7 or a Joker in the reserveSuitColonne, don't panic:
â€¢ You can swap the activator for the correct Lucky 7 of the column's suit if you retrieve it in your hand or reserve.
â€¢ The previous Joker or 7 returns to its original position.
â€¢ This swap costs one action.
â€¢ It allows unlocking progress towards the top of the column (and potentially preparing a Revolution).

sections.title: What happens in case of an attack?
content: If a Jack attacks a column activated with a 7 or a Joker:
â€¢ All cards in the column, including the activator, go to the grave.
â€¢ This cancels the column's progress.
â€¢ You will have to start over from the Ace.

sections.title: Activators and special cards (Face Cards)
content: Lucky 7s and Jokers can also be used to summon face cards:
â€¢ King â†’ 7 or Joker â†’ Grave
â€¢ Queen â†’ 7 or Joker â†’ Grave
â€¢ Jack â†’ 7 or Joker â†’ Grave
sections.warning: â— As soon as a 7 or a Joker is used to play a special card, it is immediately sent to the grave.

sections.title: Summary to remember
content: â–¶ï¸ Activate a column = Ace + 7 or Joker in the reserveSuitColonne.
ğŸ”’ To place an 8, you need the Lucky 7 of the same suit.
ğŸ” You can swap the activator if needed (single action).
ğŸ’¥ In case of attack by Jack, the column + the activator are destroyed.
ğŸ‘‘ Activators can also be used to play a King, a Queen or a Jack, but they then go to the grave.

chapters.title: The Revolution - The Ultimate Attack
chapters.subtitle: Chapter 4 â€¢ The Culmination of the Game

sections.title: The Revolution â€“ The Ultimate Attack
content: The Revolution is the supreme strategic goal in UNIT.
It is the most powerful attack in the game, the one that can turn an entire game around if well prepared.
It symbolizes the perfect completion of a full column and the execution of a flawless plan.

sections.title: Mandatory conditions to trigger a Revolution
content: To launch a Revolution, you must meet all these conditions:
âœ… Have placed all 10 cards of the same suit in order, from Ace to 10
âœ… Have not used a Joker in the column (no replacement)
âœ… Have activated the column correctly with the correct Lucky 7 of the suit
âœ… Have placed the 10 (this last one triggers the Revolution automatically)

sections.title: Immediate effects of the Revolution
content: ğŸ’¥ The opponent's King of the same suit is destroyed, even if it is still in play.
ğŸ’¥ The opponent takes 10 direct damage, with no possible defense.
ğŸª¦ The entire column (Ace to 10) is sent to the grave after the attack.
â— No Joker, Lucky 7, Jack or other effect can block a Revolution.

sections.title: Why the Revolution is unstoppable
content: The Revolution is the only completely unstoppable attack in the game.
It ignores all defense mechanisms:
âœ… Ignores Kings
âœ… Ignores Jokers
âœ… Ignores Lucky 7s
âœ… Ignores cards in reserve
âœ… Ignores any counter action
It represents a rare, but devastating event, which rewards rigorous and patient players.

sections.title: Special case: Joker in the column
content: If a single Joker replaces a card in the column:
âŒ The Revolution is blocked.
The column is considered incomplete, even if it visually looks finished.
You will have to swap the Joker for the real card (with an action) to unlock the Revolution.

sections.title: Strategic Reflection
content: The Joker is a useful but dangerous card to place in a column if you are aiming for the Revolution.
Sometimes, it is better to delay an action than to sacrifice the possibility of a Revolution.
Keeping the column pure guarantees you a brutal and spectacular outcome.

sections.title: The Perfect Revolution
content: A Perfect Revolution occurs when the player triggers a Revolution without having made any other attack with their units during the game.
ğŸ–ï¸ It testifies to absolute control of tempo, patience, and a pure playstyle.
It can surprise an overly aggressive opponent, and eliminate them in a single strike.

sections.title: Quick Summary
content: ğŸ¯ Necessary cards: Ace to 10, same suit, no Joker
ğŸ”§ Mandatory activation: Yes, with corresponding Lucky 7
âš¡ Trigger: Placing the 10
ğŸ’¥ Effects: Destruction of King + 10 direct damage
ğŸ›¡ï¸ Blockable?: No, impossible
ğŸª¦ Consequences: Entire column sent to grave
ğŸ† Strategic bonus: Perfect Revolution if no other attack made

sections.title: Defense â€“ Protecting your Health Points and Units
content: In UNIT, defense is as important as offense.
Certain cards and positions allow canceling or limiting the impact of an opponent's action.

sections.title: Objective of Defense
content: Prevent the opponent:
â€¢ From inflicting direct damage to your health points.
â€¢ From destroying your units or special cards too easily.
â€¢ From breaking your strategy (ex: preventing a Jack from clearing a column).

sections.title: The Joker â€“ Universal Defender
content: ğŸ”¹ Effect: The Joker can block any attack, regardless of the column or attacking card.
ğŸ”¹ Limit: It cannot block a Revolution.
ğŸ“‹ Usage:
â€¢ Played from hand or reserve during the opponent's turn.
â€¢ After use, it goes immediately to the grave.
ğŸ’¡ Tip: Keeping a Joker in hand is often safer than using it in attack.

sections.title: The Lucky 7 â€“ Column Shield
content: ğŸ”¹ Effect: A Lucky 7 placed in a column, at its normal position (after the 6), can block a single attack targeting that column.
ğŸ“‹ Conditions:
â€¢ The 7 must be of the same suit as the column.
â€¢ It only protects the column where it is placed.
âš¡ After use:
â€¢ The 7 is deactivated until the column is destroyed and rebuilt.
â€¢ It remains physically in play, but no longer blocks.
ğŸ’¡ Tip: A well-positioned 7 can force the opponent to waste an attack or a Joker.

sections.title: Important Interactions
content: ğŸ”¸ Classic Unit (1â€“6): Blocked by Joker âœ… | Blocked by Lucky 7 âœ…
ğŸ”¸ 8 or 9: Blocked by Joker âœ… | Blocked by Lucky 7 âœ…
ğŸ”¸ Jack: Blocked by Joker âœ… | Blocked by Lucky 7 âœ…
ğŸ”¸ King: Blocked by Joker âŒ | Blocked by Lucky 7 âŒ
ğŸ”¸ Joker: Blocked by Joker âœ… | Blocked by Lucky 7 âœ…
ğŸ”¸ Revolution (10): Blocked by Joker âŒ | Blocked by Lucky 7 âŒ

sections.title: Defensive Strategy
content: ğŸ¯ Anticipate: Keep at least one means of defense active each turn.
ğŸ¯ Protect key columns: Place a Lucky 7 on the most advanced column.
ğŸ¯ Force opponent choices: Make them believe a column is vulnerable when it is protected.
ğŸ¯ Manage resources: A Joker used too early can cost the game.

sections.title: Quick Summary
content: ğŸƒ Joker = universal defense against everything except Revolution.
7ï¸âƒ£ Lucky 7 = local defense on its column.
ğŸš« No card blocks the Revolution.

chapters.title: Strategic Shuffle â€“ Rebuilding your Deck
chapters.subtitle: Chapter 6 â€¢ The Strategic Shuffle

sections.title: Strategic Shuffle â€“ Rebuilding your Deck
content: In UNIT, it is sometimes necessary to shuffle cards from the grave with the deck to continue playing.
This action, called strategic shuffle, can be used to retrieve key cards or avoid getting stuck.

sections.title: When to perform a strategic shuffle?
content: A strategic shuffle can be performed before any other action of your turn when:
â€¢ You want to reintroduce important cards into your deck.
â€¢ You are stuck in your progress.
â€¢ Your deck is not yet empty but you want to reset the distribution.

sections.title: Rules of the strategic shuffle
content: ğŸ“… Moment:
â€¢ Must be done at the start of your turn, before discarding or drawing.
ğŸ”„ Procedure:
â€¢ You discard all cards from your hand.
â€¢ The 2 cards in reserve remain in place.
â€¢ You shuffle your deck and your grave to form a new deck.
ğŸ¥‡ First time:
â€¢ During the first strategic shuffle of the game, you can play normally after the shuffle.
ğŸ” Subsequent times:
â€¢ All strategic shuffles after the first one force you to pass your turn after the shuffle (no action possible).

sections.title: Limitations after subsequent shuffles
content: If you perform a strategic shuffle after the first one:
âŒ You cannot attack that turn.
âŒ You cannot use a Joker to defend yourself on the following opponent's turn.
âœ… A Lucky 7 already active on the field still retains its defense.

sections.title: Special Cases
content: ğŸ—‚ï¸ Empty Deck:
â€¢ If your deck is empty when drawing, you automatically shuffle the grave with the deck, without losing your turn.
â€¢ This case is not considered a strategic shuffle.
âš ï¸ Risky Strategy:
â€¢ Multiplying strategic shuffles increases randomness and can delay your plans.
â€¢ Better to keep this option as a punctual tool, not an automatism.

sections.title: Strategic Tip
content: The strategic shuffle is a double-edged sword:
âœ… It can unlock a situation...
âŒ ...but it often costs you tempo.
ğŸ’¡ Use it with a clear goal, not out of habit.
sections.highlight: ğŸ¯ Advice: Plan your strategic shuffle based on specific cards you want to retrieve, not just to 'see what happens'.

chapters.title: The Sacrifice â€“ Playing a Face Card
chapters.subtitle: Chapter 7 â€¢ The Sacrifice

sections.title: The Sacrifice â€“ Playing a Face Card
content: In UNIT, to play certain special cards called face cards (King, Queen, Jack), it is possible to use the sacrifice mechanic.
This action consists of removing cards already placed on the field to pay the summoning cost.

sections.title: Principle of Sacrifice
content: ğŸ¯ Objective: Remove a certain number of cards from the field to summon a face card.
ğŸª¦ Destination: Sacrificed cards go to the grave after use.
ğŸ“ Key Rule: Always start with the highest card of each chosen column.

sections.title: Cards impossible to sacrifice
content: âŒ Ace
âŒ Lucky 7 placed in the column
âŒ Revolution 10
âŒ Any card located under an Ace, a placed 7 or a 10: these cards are blocked and non-sacrificable.

sections.title: Selection Rules
content: ğŸ” Always start with the highest card of a column.
â€¢ Example: if the highest card in Spades is a 6â™ , you can sacrifice it.
ğŸ”„ Complete with other highest cards from other columns if necessary.
â€¢ Example: 6â™  + 8â™¥ + 2â™¦ for a King.
ğŸŒˆ Mixing suits allowed as long as each chosen card is the highest of its column.
â›“ï¸ Chain sacrifice in a column:
â€¢ You can go down from the highest to the bottom as long as no blocking card is encountered.
â€¢ Example: 6â™ , 5â™ , 4â™  in the same column.

sections.title: Summoning costs by sacrifice
content: ğŸ‘‘ King: 3 cards
ğŸ‘¸ Queen: 2 cards
ğŸƒ Jack: 1 card (8 or 9 only)

sections.title: Special Case â€“ Immediate Attack with Jack
content: If a Jack is summoned by:
â€¢ Sacrifice
â€¢ Or Joker
â¡ï¸ It can attack immediately in the same turn.
(Otherwise, it becomes passive and cannot attack until the next turn.)

sections.title: Strategic Tip
content: Sacrifice is a strong tactical choice:
âŒ You lose cards already placed...
âœ… ...but you gain a master piece.
ğŸ’¡ Use it to break opponent tempo or surprise with an immediate effect.
sections.highlight: âš”ï¸ Sacrifice transforms your present resources into immediate power. Timing is crucial!

sections.title: The King â€“ Supreme Shield
content: The King is the ultimate defensive piece in UNIT.
When in play, it fully protects your health points against attacks from units of the same suit, and forces the opponent to find a specific answer.

sections.title: King's Effect
content: As long as a King is present for a given suit:
ğŸ›¡ï¸ No unit of this suit lower than 8 can attack your health points.
ğŸ›¡ï¸ These units cannot destroy the King either.
Only certain attacks can bypass the King:
âš”ï¸ 8 or 9 of the same suit â†’ beat the King and destroy it.
ğŸƒ Joker â†’ destroys a King of any suit.
ğŸ’¥ Revolution (10) â†’ destroys the King and inflicts 10 direct damage.

sections.title: Conditions to play a King
content: Three possible methods:
âš”ï¸ Sacrifice:
â€¢ Sacrifice 3 cards, each being the highest of its column (excluding Ace, 7, 10).
ğŸƒ Joker:
â€¢ Play a Joker, which then goes to the grave.
7ï¸âƒ£ Lucky 7:
â€¢ Play a Lucky 7, which then goes to the grave.

sections.title: Positioning
content: ğŸ‘‘ The King is placed on the "King" slot of its suit on the board.
ğŸ”’ Once placed, it remains until destroyed by a valid attack.

sections.title: Loss of the King
content: If the King is beaten by an 8, 9, Joker or Revolution:
ğŸª¦ It is sent to the grave immediately.
âŒ The protection it offered disappears instantly.

sections.title: Strategy with the King
content: ğŸ›¡ï¸ Defensive: Block an advanced suit of the opponent to gain time.
â° Temporary: Force the opponent to waste an 8, 9 or Joker to clear the way.
ğŸš§ Preventive: Placing a King early can curb an entire category of the opponent.

sections.title: To Remember
content: The King does not win the game, but it can prevent the opponent from taking it from you.
Well played, it becomes a real wall in the opponent's tempo.
sections.highlight: ğŸ‘‘ The King transforms passive defense into active board control. Strategic placement can change the course of a game!

sections.title: The Queen â€“ Ladies First
content: The Queen is the only completely unassailable card in UNIT.
It can never be destroyed or prevented from accomplishing its effect.
Its main role: heal your health points.

sections.title: Absolute Immunity
content: The Queen can never be attacked by any card or effect:
âœ… Immune to Joker
âœ… Immune to Jack
âœ… Immune to classic units
Its effect triggers no matter what.

sections.title: Main Effect â€“ Heal
content: Depending on the method used to play it, the Queen heals immediately:
âš”ï¸ Sacrifice (2 cards, each the highest of its column):
â€¢ +2 HP â†’ Queen goes to grave
7ï¸âƒ£ Played with a Lucky 7:
â€¢ +2 HP â†’ Queen and 7 go to grave
ğŸƒ Played with a Joker:
â€¢ +2 HP â†’ Queen and Joker go to grave

sections.title: Secondary Effect â€“ The Good Lady's Challenge
content: If the Queen is played as the 13th card (after the 10, Jack, King, etc. in the discard or global game - advanced rule):
â€¢ It can issue a challenge: the player draws a card.
â€¢ If it's a Red card (Hearts/Diamonds): Heal doubled (+4 HP).
â€¢ If it's a Black card (Spades/Clubs): Heal canceled.
(This rule depends on the active variant).

sections.title: To Remember
content: The Queen is an instant heal.
It does not remain on the field, it performs its effect and goes to the grave.
It is the best way to recover HP in an emergency.

chapters.title: The Jack â€“ The Elimination Weapon
chapters.subtitle: Chapter 10 â€¢ The Jack

sections.title: The Jack â€“ The Elimination Weapon
content: The Jack is an offensive card in UNIT.
It is one of the most powerful ways to destroy opponent columns and apply pressure, but it has a cost: it is always sacrificed after use.

sections.title: Main Role
content: The Jack is a specialized attacker:
âš”ï¸ It can destroy an opponent unit of the same suit.
ğŸ’¥ Against small units, it is capable of sweeping an entire column.
ğŸª¦ However, it is consumed as soon as it attacks.

sections.title: Summoning the Jack
content: Three ways to bring it into play:
âš”ï¸ Sacrifice:
â€¢ Sacrifice an 8 or a 9 (highest card of a column)
â€¢ State: Immediately active
ğŸƒ Joker:
â€¢ Play a Joker (which goes to grave)
â€¢ State: Immediately active
7ï¸âƒ£ Lucky 7:
â€¢ Play a Lucky 7 (which goes to grave)
â€¢ State: Placed passive â†’ attack available only next turn

sections.title: Operating Cycle
content: âš¡ Active:
â€¢ Can immediately attack an opponent unit of the same suit.
â€¢ After its attack, the Jack is sent to the grave.
ğŸ˜´ Passive:
â€¢ If placed via a Lucky 7, the Jack cannot attack this turn.
â€¢ It becomes active at the start of the next turn.

sections.title: Authorized Targets
content: The Jack can attack:
âœ… A unit of value â‰¤ 6 â†’ the entire opponent column is destroyed (column sent to grave + Jack to grave).
âš ï¸ A unit of 8 or 9 â†’ direct combat, result depending on rules (risk of losing the Jack).
The Jack cannot attack:
âŒ A Queen (protected by Ladies First).
âŒ A King.
âŒ Another Joker.

sections.title: Example Actions
content: ğŸ¯ Active Jack â†’ attacks a 5â™  â†’ entire opponent Spade column is destroyed, Jack also goes to grave.
âš ï¸ Active Jack â†’ attacks an 8â™¥ â†’ risky combat, Jack can be countered.
âš ï¸ Active Jack â†’ attacks a 9â™¦ â†’ same, possible counter.

sections.title: Strategy with the Jack
content: ğŸ’¥ Breakthrough weapon: destroy an advanced opponent column to break their tempo.
âš–ï¸ Calculated sacrifice: losing a Jack to force the opponent to rebuild an entire column can be worth it.
âš¡ Immediate combo: summoning a Jack via a Joker or sacrifice allows attacking directly and surprising the opponent.
â° Timing: waiting for the opponent to invest heavily in a column before destroying it maximizes the Jack's value.

sections.title: To Remember
content: The Jack is a double-edged sword: it destroys, but destroys itself with it.
Well played, it can turn a game around in a single action.
sections.highlight: ğŸ—¡ï¸ The Jack embodies tactical sacrifice: losing to win better. Its timing of use can determine the outcome of a game!

chapters.title: The Joker â€“ The Legendary Card
chapters.subtitle: Chapter 11 â€¢ The Joker

sections.title: The Joker â€“ The Legendary Card
content: The Joker is the most powerful and versatile card in UNIT.
It is a unique card, capable of intervening in almost all phases of the game: attack, defense, activation, healing, or even temporary replacement.
But be careful: each use of the Joker is single-use and always has a significant consequence.

sections.title: The Joker's Roles
content: The Joker can be used in 5 main ways:
âš”ï¸ Attack (destroy units or face cards)
ğŸ›¡ï¸ Defense (block an attack)
ğŸ”„ Replace (temporarily hold the place of a missing card)
ğŸ’Š Heal (+3 health points)
ğŸ”§ Activate a column or a face card (like a Lucky 7)

sections.title: Offensive Use â€“ Attack
content: The Joker can destroy any unit in an opponent column, even if it is not the highest.
Effects:
â€¢ The destroyed card is sent to the grave.
â€¢ All cards above become unusable until the column is rebuilt.
Example: if a Joker destroys a 6â™£, then the 7â™£, 8â™£, 9â™£ and 10â™£ can no longer be played until the chain is repaired.
The Joker can also:
âœ… Destroy a King (regardless of suit)
âœ… Destroy a Jack (regardless of suit)
ğŸš« Limits:
âŒ Cannot attack an Ace
âŒ Cannot attack a Lucky 7
âŒ Cannot attack a Revolution 10

sections.title: Defensive Use â€“ Blocking
content: The Joker can be played from hand or reserve during the opponent's turn.
âœ… Effect: it blocks any attack (unit, Jack, opponent Joker, etc.).
ğŸš« Sole exception: it cannot block a Revolution.
After use, it goes to the grave.

sections.title: Use as Replacement (Substitution)
content: The Joker can be placed on the field to temporarily replace a missing card in a column.
This allows continuing to build the column without waiting for the real card.
âš ï¸ Important consequences:

sections.title: To Remember
content: The Joker is the most flexible and dangerous card in UNIT.
Used poorly, it can block your own strategies (especially Revolution).
Used well, it can save a game or destroy the opponent's plan at the decisive moment.
